q: What are the common symptoms of Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome?
a: Common symptoms of Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome include muscle weakness, fatigue, difficulty walking, drooping eyelids, dry eyes, swallowing problems, dizziness upon standing, a dry mouth, constipation, and erectile dysfunction.

q: How is Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome diagnosed?
a: Diagnosis of Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome involves a medical history review, physical examination, reflex tests, blood tests to detect antibodies, nerve studies, and scans like CT or PET scans if lung cancer is suspected.

q: What are the treatment options for Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome?
a: There is no cure for Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome, but treatments include managing lung cancer if present, medications to improve nerve-muscle communication, immunosuppressants, plasmapheresis, and immunoglobulin therapy.

q: What is the outlook for Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome?
a: Some people respond well to treatment and can keep their symptoms under control, while others may find their everyday activities and quality of life affected. Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome does not affect life expectancy if it's not associated with cancer.

q: How does Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome affect life expectancy?
a: People with Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome and lung cancer tend to have a shorter life expectancy, as it becomes difficult to treat at that stage. However, if LEMS is not associated with cancer, it does not affect life expectancy.

q: What kind of information is passed on to the National Congenital Anomaly and Rare Disease Registration Service for LEMS patients?
a: For LEMS patients, their clinical team may pass information to the National Congenital Anomaly and Rare Disease Registration Service to help scientists find better ways to prevent and treat the condition. Patients can choose to opt out of the register at any time.

q: Are there any specific symptoms or complications related to LEMS in people with lung cancer?
a: In people with lung cancer, LEMS may cause additional symptoms such as aching muscles, limited mobility, and weakness that worsens over time. It can also lead to a shorter life expectancy.

q: How can muscle weakness caused by LEMS be managed?
a: Muscle weakness caused by LEMS can be managed through various treatment options, including medication to improve nerve-muscle communication, immunosuppressants, plasmapheresis, immunoglobulin therapy, and managing any underlying lung cancer.

q: What triggers the immune system to attack the nerves in LEMS?
a: The exact cause of the immune system attacking the nerves in LEMS is unknown. It is often associated with lung cancer, but it can also occur in individuals without cancer.

q: What tests are done to diagnose LEMS?
a: To diagnose LEMS, a medical history review, physical examination, reflex tests, blood tests to detect antibodies, nerve studies, and scans like CT or PET scans for lung cancer detection may be done.

q: What is Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome (LEMS)?
a: LEMS is a rare condition that affects the signals between the nerves and muscles, leading to muscle weakness and other symptoms. It can occur in people with or without lung cancer.

q: What are the symptoms of LEMS?
a: Symptoms of LEMS include weakness in the legs, arms, neck, and face, as well as fatigue, difficulty walking, drooping eyelids, swallowing problems, and more. It's recommended to see a GP if you experience a combination of these symptoms.

q: What causes LEMS?
a: LEMS is caused by the immune system mistakenly attacking and damaging the nerves. The exact trigger is unknown, but it is often associated with lung cancer.

q: How is LEMS diagnosed?
a: To diagnose LEMS, the GP may check your medical history, perform a physical examination, test your reflexes, and refer you to a neurologist for further tests. These tests may include blood tests, nerve studies, and scans to check for lung cancer.

q: What are the treatments for LEMS?
a: While there is currently no cure for LEMS, treatments can help reduce the symptoms. These can include treating lung cancer (if present), medication to improve nerve signals to the muscles, and immunosuppressants to reduce immune system activity.

q: What is the outlook for LEMS?
a: The outlook for LEMS varies. Some respond well to treatment and can manage their symptoms, while others find it affects their daily activities and quality of life. LEMS without cancer does not significantly impact life expectancy.

q: What is the National Congenital Anomaly and Rare Disease Registration Service (NCARDRS)?
a: NCARDRS is a service that collects information about individuals with rare diseases like LEMS to aid researchers in finding better prevention and treatment methods. You can choose to opt out of the register at any time.

q: How can LEMS be managed?
a: LEMS can be managed through various treatments such as medications to improve nerve signals, immunosuppressants, plasmapheresis, and immunoglobulin therapy. It is best to consult with a healthcare professional for personalized management plans.

q: Can LEMS be cured?
a: Although there is no cure for LEMS, treatments can help reduce the symptoms and manage the condition. The goal of treatment is to improve muscle strength and quality of life.

q: Are there any lifestyle changes that can help with LEMS?
a: While there are no specific lifestyle changes that cure LEMS, maintaining a healthy lifestyle, including regular exercise, a balanced diet, and managing stress, can help improve overall well-being and may indirectly benefit those with LEMS.
